ðŸ”¥ LinkPure | Dart
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Automatically cleaning and simplifying URLs copied to the clipboard by removing tracking parameters and unwrapping redirect links.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Automatic URL Rewriting â€¢ Rule Management â€¢ Built-in Shared Rules â€¢ Rule Testing â€¢ System Notifications
ðŸ“– Summary: LinkPure is a cross-platform application designed to automatically rewrite URLs copied to the clipboard based on user-defined rules. It offers a visual interface for rule management, includes over 1000 pre-configured rules for cleaning tracking parameters and unwrapping redirects, and provides system notifications for rewritten URLs.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸš€ WebDeck | Jinja
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: To provide a software-based, customizable remote control interface for computers, acting as a free alternative to dedicated hardware like the Elgato Stream Deck.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Flask web application for remote computer control â€¢ Browser-based interface accessible from any device â€¢ Touchscreen optimized for intuitive interaction â€¢ Customizable buttons and shortcuts â€¢ Free alternative to physical Stream Deck hardware
ðŸ“– Summary: WebDeck is a free, open-source alternative to physical Stream Decks. It's a Flask web application that allows users to control their computer remotely via any browser-enabled device with a touchscreen, offering a customizable interface for shortcuts and commands.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸš€ gomlx | Go
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Developing and training machine learning models in Go with high performance and broad hardware acceleration.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Differentiable operators â€¢ Pure Go backend (runs everywhere Go runs, including WASM) â€¢ Optimized backend with OpenXLA (CPU, GPU, TPU support) â€¢ Just-in-time compilation â€¢ Distributed execution support (multi-TPU/GPU)
ðŸ“– Summary: GoMLX is an accelerated machine learning and generic math framework for Go, designed to be a PyTorch/Jax/TensorFlow equivalent for the Go ecosystem. It supports a pure Go backend for broad compatibility and an optimized backend using OpenXLA for high-performance computation on CPUs, GPUs, and TPUs, including distributed training.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸ”¥ resterm | Go
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: A terminal-native client for developers to efficiently test, debug, and interact with various network APIs and protocols without leaving their keyboard.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Terminal-based client for HTTP, GraphQL, gRPC, WebSocket, SSE â€¢ Keyboard-driven interface â€¢ Local data storage (.http/.rest files) â€¢ Built-in SSH tunnels â€¢ OAuth 2.0 support (client credentials, password grant, authorization code + PKCE)
ðŸ“– Summary: Resterm is a powerful terminal-based client designed for interacting with various network protocols including HTTP, GraphQL, gRPC, WebSockets, and SSE. It emphasizes a keyboard-driven workflow and local data storage, offering features like SSH tunnels, OAuth 2.0 support, and a custom scripting language for complex request logic.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸš€ gojekyll | Go
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Building and serving static websites with a focus on speed and developer experience, as an alternative to Jekyll.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Fast static site generation (approx. 20x faster than Jekyll) â€¢ Live reload and directory watch for `serve` command â€¢ Partial Jekyll compatibility â€¢ Liquid templating language support â€¢ SASS support
ðŸ“– Summary: Gojekyll is a Go-based implementation of the Jekyll static site generator, offering faster build times and live reloading. It aims for partial compatibility with Jekyll, supporting Liquid templating and Sass, and provides `build` and `serve` commands.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source
